definitions.definition: To act in a manner such that one has fun ; to engage in activities expressly for the purpose of recreation or entertainment .
examples: The children played in the park.

definitions.definition: To toy or trifle ; to act with levity or thoughtlessness ; to be careless .
examples: Don't play with your food!
He's just playing with her affections.
definitions.label_groups: intransitive , especially with 'with'; see also play with

definitions.definition: To perform in (a sport ); to participate in (a game ).
examples: He plays on three teams.
Who's playing now?
play football, play sports, play games

subdefinitions.definition: Specifying a particular sporting role or position.
examples: He plays left back for Mudchester Rovers

subdefinitions.definition: To compete against , in a game .
examples: We're playing one of the top teams in the next round.

subdefinitions.definition: To be the opposing score to.
examples: Look at the score now ... 23 plays 8!
subdefinitions.label_groups: transitive , in the scoring of games and sports

definitions.definition: To contend or fight using weapons, both as practice or in real life-or-death combats ; to engage in martial games; to joust ; to fence
To act or behave in a stated way.
examples: to play safe, to play fair, to play dirty

subdefinitions.definition: To give a false appearance of being ; to pretend to be .
examples: He plays dumb, but actually he's very clever.
Stop playing the fool.
No part of the brain plays the role of permanent memory.

subdefinitions.definition: To portray (a character ) in (a film or theatre ).
examples: Who played Scarlett O'Hara in 'Gone with the Wind'?

definitions.definition: To produce sound (especially music ), moving pictures , or theatrical performance .

subdefinitions.definition: To produce music using a musical instrument .
examples: I'll play the piano and you sing.
Can you play an instrument?
I've practiced the piano off and on, but I still can't play very well.
subdefinitions.label_groups: transitive , intransitive , especially of a person

examples: This piano plays out of tune.

subdefinitions.definition: To operate (a device or media ) so as to cause sound (especially music) or moving pictures to be produced.
examples: You can play the DVD now.
Don't play your radio so loud!
Play the audio clip to hear how the word is pronounced.

subdefinitions.definition: To render (a musical title , compositional style , film title, etc.) using a musical instrument or device.
examples: Do you know how to play Für Elise on the piano?
We especially like to play jazz together.
She keeps playing 'Achy Breaky Heart' over and over again on her stereo.

subdefinitions.definition: To emit or relay sound (especially music) or moving pictures; ( of a device ) to operate media .
examples: The juke box is playing our favourite song.
The radio was playing in the background.
This DVD is scratched and won't play .
Channel 9 is playing that old comedy series again.
My cassette player won't play this worn-out old tape.
subdefinitions.label_groups: transitive , intransitive , of a device, media, broadcast, etc.

subdefinitions.definition: To be performed , reproduced , or shown .
examples: His latest film is playing in the local theatre tomorrow.
Some kind of lounge music was playing in the background.
subdefinitions.label_groups: intransitive , of a theatrical performance , film or music

subdefinitions.definition: To perform or give performances in or at (a venue or location ).
examples: The band is playing large arenas nationwide.
labels: of a theatrical company or band
subdefinitions.label_groups: transitive , of a theatrical company or band , etc.

examples: to play a comedy

definitions.definition: To move briskly , sweepingly , back and forth , in a directed manner , etc.

subdefinitions.definition: To move in a light or brisk manner.
examples: The fountain plays .
The leaves played in the wind.

subdefinitions.definition: To move so as to fall upon or sweep across something, or to direct or operate (something) in such a manner.
examples: The torch beam played around the room.
They played the jet of water onto the seat of the fire.
to play cannon upon a fortification

subdefinitions.definition: To move in an alternating or reciprocal manner; to move to and fro .

definitions.definition: To bring into action or motion ; to exhibit in action; to execute or deploy .
examples: That was a great shot he played !
He played the blue ball, but the green would have been a better choice.
When you're in a team, you have to play your part.
to play a trump in a card game, to play tricks, to play a joke

definitions.definition: To handle or deal with (a matter or situation ) in a stated way.
examples: The bank robbers have three hostages inside, so we're going to have to play this very carefully.

definitions.definition: To handle or deal with (something) in a calculating manner intended to achieve profit or gain .
examples: He made a fortune on Wall Street, playing the markets.
In this business you have to play the percentages.

definitions.definition: To be received or accepted (in a given way); to go down .
examples: This policy plays well with younger voters.
How will this play in the swing states?

definitions.definition: To keep in play , as a hooked fish in order to land it.

examples: You played me!

definitions.definition: To kid ; to joke ; to say something for amusement ; to act , or to treat something, unseriously .
examples: They don't play with the rules around here.

definitions.definition: To take part in amorous activity; to make love ; see also play around .
For additional senses in various idiomatic phrases, see the individual entries, such as play along , play at , play down , play off , play on , play out , play to , play up , etc.

main_definition: ( intransitive ) To act in a manner such that one has fun ; to engage in activities expressly for the purpose of recreation or entertainment .
secondary_definitions: ( intransitive , especially with 'with'; see also play with ) To toy or trifle ; to act with levity or thoughtlessness ; to be careless .
( transitive , intransitive ) To perform in (a sport ); to participate in (a game ).
( intransitive ) To contend or fight using weapons, both as practice or in real life-or-death combats ; to engage in martial games; to joust ; to fence
( intransitive , copulative ) To act or behave in a stated way.
( transitive ) To act as (the indicated role ).
( transitive , intransitive ) To produce sound (especially music ), moving pictures , or theatrical performance .
( transitive , intransitive ) To move briskly , sweepingly , back and forth , in a directed manner , etc.
( transitive ) To bring into action or motion ; to exhibit in action; to execute or deploy .
( transitive ) To handle or deal with (a matter or situation ) in a stated way.
( transitive ) To handle or deal with (something) in a calculating manner intended to achieve profit or gain .
( intransitive ) To be received or accepted (in a given way); to go down .
( transitive ) To keep in play , as a hooked fish in order to land it.
( transitive , colloquial ) To manipulate , deceive , or swindle .
( African-American Vernacular , intransitive ) To kid ; to joke ; to say something for amusement ; to act , or to treat something, unseriously .
( intransitive ) To take part in amorous activity; to make love ; see also play around .
For additional senses in various idiomatic phrases, see the individual entries, such as play along , play at , play down , play off , play on , play out , play to , play up , etc.
